awd_titl_txt: CRCNS US-German-Israeli Collaborative Research Proposal: Hierarchical Coordination of Complex Actions
awd_abstract_narration:
There are many arenas where humans outperform machines. For example, when coordinated interaction with the physical environment is needed, humans (and animals) vastly out-perform modern robots.  This occurs despite the biological systems having far slower 'hardware' and 'wetware' and much greater complexity than even the most modern robots. This research project seeks to understand the role of complexity in human sensory and motor performance. Human walking under challenging balance conditions will be studied and the use of canes to enhance stability will be included.  The investigators emphasis on learning to balance in challenging environments should lead to new rehabilitation therapies (with or without robotic assistance) to aid recovery of balance and walking (e.g., after stroke). The researchers will create educational units suitable for online presentation to K-12 students and will devise exhibits based on their research for the Museum of Science in Boston.

The central hypothesis to be tested in this project is that complex movements involving physical interaction with objects are organized as a hierarchy formed of modules or primitives. Experiments will study how unimpaired humans learn to walk on narrow beams. Beams of different roundness will vary the challenge. Hand-held canes will alter the available support (like training wheels on a child's bicycle). Computer simulations combined with machine learning will study the benefits and drawbacks of organization as a hierarchy. New mathematical tools will be developed and tested to see if they enable insightful description of human performance in challenging conditions. The research involves a multinational collaboration among scientists from the U.S., Israel, and Germany, each with complementary expertise. The bridge between experimental and theoretical work and the diverse Principal Investigators will help to attract women into the traditionally male-dominated fields of computational neuroscience, robotics and control engineering.

Companion projects are being funded by the Federal Ministry of Education and Research, Germany (BMBF) and the US-Israel Binational Science Foundation (BSF).

por.por_cntn:
To gain insight into the human control of voluntary movements, research in motor neuroscience has employed highly simplified testbeds, such as reaching in a horizontal plane, to avoid uncontrolled variability and facilitate quantification. However, the human sensorimotor system is high-dimensional, nonlinear, and hierarchical, and in constant interaction with the environment such that insights into simplified experimental preparations may not ?scale up? to the complex behaviors in the real world. To embrace the full high-dimensional problem, this project chose the whole-body task of standing and walking on narrow support to gain insight into the essential challenge of maintaining balance. 

Intellectual Merit:

Even simply maintaining upright stance requires sophisticated neuro-muscular control as evident in the increased risk of falling in the elderly and virtually all neurological disorders. Experimental data of ground reaction forces, particularlydirections of the forces, revealed a consistent pattern of frequency-dependent force directions during quiet standing. Replicating these features required a human model with at least two joints, a double inverted pendulum, with a controller that actuated torques at ankle and hip joints, i.e., controlling the interaction between the foot and the ground. When upright stance was supported by two hand-held canes, experimental data revealed an intricate pattern of mechanical and sensory effects that stabilized the stance. Manual forces exerted on the canes and ground reaction forces showed that while canes reduced the variability of the center of pressure and center of mass, collective metrics of the whole body, forces on the canes beyond the preferred level yielded no further benefits. In fact, they had a destabilizing effect, as pushing destabilized the inverted pendulum of the cane. Taken together, maintaining stability during upright stance results from the subtle interactions of the hand and feet with supporting surfaces.

A series of experimental studies of humans walking on a narrow beam took these insights into even more complex behavior. A first study on unimpaired humans walking on a narrow beam revealed that stability of the entire multi-segmented body is best captured by analyzing angular momentum of the whole body, not kinematics. Principal component analyses of angular momentum around the base of support revealed surprisingly low dimensionality with consistent patterns across individuals, unlike kinematics of joints or endpoints. Given that in motor neuroscience studies on reaching movements have focused on endpoint motions as the primary source of information to infer control, it is non-trivial that it is a metric defined over the entire body, that reveals low-dimensional structure. When the body?s dimensionality was constrained by wearing flat rigid soles, i.e., fixating the degrees of freedom of the feet, balancing on the narrow beam became more stable, likely due to increased contact forces. Similar effects were observed when stiffening the arms, constraining the dimensionality of the arms and shoulders. Inverse dynamics analysis the 3D multi-body human walking on a narrow beam revealed more vigorous arm movements when the center of mass approached the boundary of support. Forward dynamic simulations showed that shoulder joint torques generated by an optimal controller were similar to those in humans, suggesting that humans successfully use their arms to maximally maintain balance in challenging walking conditions.  

However, these studies on manipulating stability by additional constraints also showed that this gain in stability did not transfer to walking without foot or arm support. The absence of any after-effects suggested that the improved balance was the result of a mechanical effect rather than a change in neural control. This absence of adaptation raised the question of how longer-term improvements in balance and changes in the neural control of balance might be obtained. To address this question of trainability, a meta-analysis of 107 published studies evaluated the effect of interactive video training devices, used over training periods of 4 to 12 weeks for all subject groups. The results in healthy individuals and those with neurological disorders collectively demonstrated moderate to high effectiveness of such longer-term practice. While such improvements are promising, it remains unanswered whether these improvements persist and enhance stability and safety in real-life activities.

Broader Impacts: 

Going beyond scientific reduction, our experimental and modeling studies revealed that simple metrics of endeffector motions are insufficient to uncover the subtle control mechanisms in whole-body balance control. In addition to scientific advances, the results have a range of clinical implications. Improving balance in standing and walking may alleviate the serious problem of falling in older and neurologically-impaired individuals. In particular, our results may inform how older individuals or patients with neurological disorders should best use secondary supports and clarify which interventions may lead to lasting recovery, not only mechanical compensation. The insights may also lead to control algorithms for robots that can maneuver in challenging terrains. The research involved and two undergraduate, two graduate students and two postdocs and its results were disseminated widely in conference presentations and scientific journals.
